intro: Clinopodium caucasicum, commonly known as Caucasian mint, is a perennial herb native to the Caucasus region. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pale blue to purple and appear in whorled clusters. The aromatic properties of its leaves make it a valuable plant in traditional medicine and herbal remedies.
